title: 109_hr4953
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 2006". Congress recognizes the changing fish and wildlife communities in the Great Lakes and emphasizes the importance of ecosystem-based management. It is deemed necessary to support sustainable resources in the Great Lakes Basin and improve coordination for effective conservation efforts. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act allows for funding to support the management of fish and wildlife resources in the Great Lakes Basin. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. Section 1004 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is amended by redesignating paragraphs and adding a definition for "regional project" related to fish and wildlife resource protection. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is amended to include a definition for "regional project" related to fish and wildlife resource protection in the Great Lakes basin. SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION, REVIEW, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROPOSALS. Amends Section 1005 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 to focus on the identification, review, and implementation of proposals and regional projects. The Director is tasked with encouraging the development and implementation of fish and wildlife restoration proposals and regional projects, particularly in the Great Lakes Basin. They work in cooperation with State Directors and Indian Tribes to identify and implement these projects, subject to the availability of appropriations. Additionally, the Director annually requests proposals or regional projects from State Directors and Indian Tribes for the restoration of fish and wildlife resources. The Director encourages fish and wildlife restoration proposals and regional projects in the Great Lakes Basin, following specific requirements and agreements. The Great Lakes Fishery Commission retains authority to manage sea lamprey populations in the Great Lakes Basin, in accordance with various conservation acts and plans. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Proposal Review Committee is established to review proposals aimed at minimizing sea lamprey populations in the Great Lakes Basin. The committee consists of representatives from State Directors, Indian Tribes, and experts in wildlife management. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Proposal Review Committee consists of representatives from State Directors, Indian Tribes, and experts in wildlife management. Members serve at the pleasure of the appointing State Director or Tribal Chair, with the Great Lakes Coordinator of the US Fish and Wildlife Service participating as an observer. Committee members must recuse themselves from proposals they have submitted. The Committee meets annually to review and assess proposals and special projects for effectiveness. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Proposal Review Committee evaluates proposals and special projects for their effectiveness and appropriateness. They recommend funding for selected projects to the Director for implementation based on set criteria and goals. The Director considers effectiveness and appropriateness of proposals and regional projects in fulfilling laws for Great Lakes Basin restoration. Cost sharing requires 25% non-Federal contribution, exempt for certain regional projects. The Director determines that federal funds cannot be used as a non-Federal cost-share for the project. This exclusion does not impact Indian tribes under a different cost-sharing requirement. SEC. 5 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is amended to focus on restoring and maintaining self-sustaining fish and wildlife resources. SEC. 6 establishes offices. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is amended to establish the Great Lakes Coordination Office, responsible for coordinating all US Fish and Wildlife Service activities in the Great Lakes Basin, including intra- and interagency coordination, information distribution, and public outreach. The Lower Great Lakes Fishery Resources Office shall ensure information availability to the public and report to the Director of Region 3, Great Lakes Big Rivers. Responsibilities include operational activities related to fishery resource protection and restoration. The Upper Great Lakes Fishery Resources Office is responsible for operational activities related to fishery resource protection, restoration, maintenance, and enhancement in the Upper Great Lakes. SEC. 7. REPORTS. Section 1008 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is amended to read as follows: "SEC. 1008. REPORTS." The Director must submit a report by December 31, 2011, to the House and Senate committees detailing actions taken, results of proposals, and progress towards goals. Additionally, annual reports must be submitted by December 31 of fiscal years 2007 through 2012 to the Great Lakes States and Indian Tribes outlining the same information. The Director, in consultation with relevant agencies, shall conduct a study on the fish and wildlife resources of the Great Lakes Basin by December 16, 2009. The Director will conduct a study on the fish and wildlife resources of the Great Lakes Basin and submit a comprehensive report to the Senate and House committees by June 30, 2006. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends Section 1009 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 to authorize appropriations. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2007 through 2012: $12,000,000 for fish and wildlife restoration proposals, $6,000,000 for regional projects by the US Fish and Wildlife Service, and $2,000,000 for the Great Lake Coordination Office. The Great Lake Coordination Office in East Lansing, Michigan, the Upper Great Lakes Fishery Resources Office, and the Lower Great Lakes Fishery Resources Office operate under section 1007.
